message.content:
We can “back‐into” the ending inventory value by “tracking” how many of each product were purchased (at the cost paid for them) and then reducing that by the cost (the “cost_amount” shown on sale transactions) of sold units. In our case the “inventorized” items are those bought in the Purchase entries (with product IDs P001–P004) and then later sold in the Sale entries.

Step 1. – Sum up purchases by product

• P001 (Heavy Equipment A):
 – From Purchase20231231002: 1 unit at 500,000  
 – From Purchase20231231007: 2 units at 500,000 each → 1,000,000  
 – From Purchase20231231009: 2 units at 500,000 each → 1,000,000  
 – From Purchase20231231010: 1 unit at 500,000  
 – From Purchase20231231011: 1 unit at 500,000  
 – From Purchase20231231013: 1 unit at 500,000  
  Total purchased: 1+2+2+1+1+1 = 8 units  
  Total cost = 500,000 + 1,000,000 + 1,000,000 + 500,000 + 500,000 + 500,000 = 4,000,000

• P002 (Heavy Equipment B):
 – From Purchase20231231003: 2 units at 800,000 each → 1,600,000  
 – From Purchase20231231008: 2 units at 800,000 each → 1,600,000  
  Total purchased: 2+2 = 4 units  
  Total cost = 1,600,000 + 1,600,000 = 3,200,000

• P003 (Heavy Equipment C):
 – From Purchase20231231005: 1 unit at 1,000,000  
 – From Purchase20231231006: 2 units at 1,000,000 each → 2,000,000  
 – From Purchase20231231014: 1 unit at 1,000,000  
  Total purchased: 1+2+1 = 4 units  
  Total cost = 1,000,000 + 2,000,000 + 1,000,000 = 4,000,000

• P004 (Heavy Equipment D):
 – From Purchase20231231001: 1 unit at 1,500,000  
 – From Purchase20231231004: 2 units at 1,500,000 each → 3,000,000  
 – From Purchase20231231012: 1 unit at 1,500,000  
  Total purchased: 1+2+1 = 4 units  
  Total cost = 1,500,000 + 3,000,000 + 1,500,000 = 6,000,000

Step 2. – Sum up sales (using the “cost_amount” given in each sale row to represent the cost removed from inventory)

Looking at the sale transactions that mention our products we obtain:

• P001:
 – Sale20240106004: sold 1 unit – cost 500,000  
 – Sale20240114010: sold 1 unit – cost 500,000  
 – Sale20240122019: sold 1 unit – cost 500,000  
 – Sale20240124022: sold 1 unit – cost 500,000  
 – Sale20240126025: sold 1 unit – cost 500,000  
 – Sale20240131033: sold 1 unit – cost 500,000  
 – Sale20240202035: sold 1 unit – cost 500,000  
  Total sold: 7 units  
  Total cost = 7 × 500,000 = 3,500,000

• P002:
 – Sale20240111008: sold 1 unit – cost 800,000  
 – Sale20240123021: sold 1 unit – cost 800,000  
  Total sold: 2 units  
  Total cost = 2 × 800,000 = 1,600,000

• P003:
 – Sale20240119016: sold 1 unit – cost 1,000,000  
 – Sale20240130031: sold 1 unit – cost 1,000,000  
  Total sold: 2 units  
  Total cost = 2,000,000

• P004:
 – Sale20240108006: sold 1 unit – cost 1,500,000  
 – Sale20240125024: sold 1 unit – cost 1,500,000  
 – Sale20240204038: sold 1 unit – cost 1,500,000  
  Total sold: 3 units  
  Total cost = 3 × 1,500,000 = 4,500,000

Step 3. – Calculate ending inventory

For each product the ending inventory is the purchased cost minus the sold cost:

• P001: Ending cost = 4,000,000 – 3,500,000 = 500,000  
• P002: Ending cost = 3,200,000 – 1,600,000 = 1,600,000  
• P003: Ending cost = 4,000,000 – 2,000,000 = 2,000,000  
• P004: Ending cost = 6,000,000 – 4,500,000 = 1,500,000  

Total ending inventory = 500,000 + 1,600,000 + 2,000,000 + 1,500,000 = 5,600,000

Step 4. – Determine the change in inventory

If there is no opening balance (other than what was purchased during the period) then the ending inventory of 5,600,000 represents an increase in inventory over the period. In the cash flow statement an increase in inventory is shown as a use of cash (a “decrease” in cash flow).

Thus the “(Increase) Decrease in Inventory” line item is –5,600,000.00

-------------------------------------------------

{
  "solution": {
    "(Increase) Decrease in Inventory": "-5600000.00"
  }
}
